video.title: FANTASY LIFE i: The Girl Who Steals Time | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
A life sim set in a fantasy world called Fantasy 
Life. Boy, that&#39;s got to be a new frontrunner

for Most on-the-Nose Title, right after Space 
Quest. And Blood. And Press Buttons to Win. &quot;Oh,

good point, Yahtz, suppose we&#39;d better 
massively overcomplicate things. There,

now it&#39;s called Fantasy Life i: The Girl 
Who Steals Time.&quot; Well, that&#39;s what happens

when you don&#39;t put a fence around your 
herb garden, I suppose. Fantasy Life i:

The Girl From Ipanema was recommended to me 
by a weeb of my acquaintance who said, &quot;Hey,

I know you always talk shit about games that try 
to be everything at once. Well, here&#39;s a game

that actually pulls it off. It&#39;s Animal Crossing 
but also Stardew Valley AND Breath of the Wild

with a little dusting of Miitopia for taste.&quot; To 
which I replied, &quot;That&#39;s not everything; that&#39;s

four things.&quot; And then he realized the error of 
his life, and everyone stood up and clapped. The

game opens with our protagonist—custom crafted 
in a visual style with a pretty terminal case of

Nintendo Mii syndrome, or Miixamotosis—sailing the 
S.S. Inevitable Prologue Shipwreck to a distant

land with a very &quot;the Professor Layton we have 
at home&quot; sort of dude and a small crew of gonks.

Then, the usual stuff happens. You know, a giant 
nightmare dragon appears, the dragon fossil we&#39;re

transporting comes to life and fights it, we 
ride it through a magic portal into the past,

blah de blah de blah. Things only get interesting 
again when we wake up on an island beach with a

faceful of crab urine and then have to report 
to the king of the island to apologize for

crashing our skeleton dragon into it and exchange 
insurance information. At more or less this point,

we are told we need to choose a character 
class. &quot;Do you want to be a knight, a mercenary,

or a wizard?&quot; Ah, the classic triumvirate. I think 
today I- &quot;Or a hunter, a miner, a lumberjack,

or a fisherman?&quot; W- &quot;Or a carpenter, a tailor, 
a blacksmith, an alchemist, a chef, an artist,

or a farmer?&quot; I&#39;m sorry, I&#39;m confused. I thought 
I was building an RPG character, but I seem to

have wandered into a career guidance counsellor&#39;s 
office. The game presents this like we&#39;re choosing

what single role in society we wish to fill 
for the rest of our life and casually mentions,

&quot;Hey, probably no harm in trying out a couple 
of the others as well, but don&#39;t sweat it.&quot;

No. The game is lying to you. Do sweat it. You 
have to sweat it. What you need to be doing

at this point is enrolling in every single 
fucking career. Because if you don&#39;t start

putting levels into lumberjacking now, then 
some time later, you&#39;re going to be exploring

a dungeon and there&#39;ll be a fuck off great level 
25 pine tree blocking one of the tunnels, sitting

there mocking your dainty, uncalloused palms. 
Fortunately, while each career has an opening

story quest to introduce the skills involved, you 
have the option of skipping those after the first

and instead just getting a quick crash course on 
how to stand next to a tree and press the &quot;hit

with axe&quot; button. You need all the job skills 
because—spoiler alert—the final challenge of

the story campaign is to construct a world-saving 
MacGuffin device made from metal, stone, cloth,

and fish. Which has to be tailored, blacksmithed, 
carpentered, artistically beautified, and then

fed a tasty meal. But as for the actual gameplay 
involved in executing all these different skills,

you&#39;ll be relieved to hear that none of 
them stray too far from the core skill of

pressing the X button a lot. Basically, 
all the crafting jobs are the same:

you go around a table pressing X over one of three 
workstations to satisfy a row of icons within a

time limit. It&#39;s like trying to get an orgy going 
with three extremely-difficult-to-please people.

Okay, you don&#39;t actually need to learn every skill 
because if you explore the sandbox Breath of the

Wild dimension that&#39;s kept separate to everything 
else and complete the challenge rooms that are

not Breath of the Wild shrines, stop calling 
them that, there&#39;s a chance you&#39;ll rescue a

lumberjack to add to your village, and while 
they&#39;re in your party, they can take care of

any trees you&#39;re finding particularly frightening 
and aggressive. Assuming you level them up enough,

but the whole party shares any experience you 
get, so I guess watching you murder direwolves

and sew together new undergarments inspires 
them to hold their axe better. So basically,

there are three different worlds in play—the past 
(where you pursue the plot and crawl dungeons),

the aforementioned Breath of the Wild side 
hustle dimension (where you fill out the map,

hunt secrets, and grind your skills), and the 
present (where you build and decorate a little

farm/Animal Crossing village full of rescued 
laborers and pretend they&#39;re your friends). Now,

as is so often the case, if you focus on any 
single element of Fantasy Life i: The Girl With

the Dragon Tattoo, it&#39;s not gonna hold up. The 
combat&#39;s about as complex as Hungry Hungry Hippos.

I was maining as a wizard and breezed all the way 
through past the final boss with no difficulty

because half the enemies didn&#39;t even have ranged 
attacks and the other half seemed perplexed by

the very concept of me getting out of the way. 
You go through Breath of the Wild land with some

kind of crippling neck injury that means you can&#39;t 
look up, which is a definite handicap for someone

trying to explore hilly terrain; I had to climb 
every hill to see if there was a puzzle shrine

there or just another 500 of that one flower 
that&#39;s only useful for crafting printer toner

for the temporary office worker class, and even 
if it is a puzzle shrine, it&#39;s probably gonna be

one of those fucking Simon memory challenges that 
hold you up like a fucking highway patrolman who

got yelled at by his wife this morning. In the 
Animal Crossing village bit, all you can build

is a tiny cult compound full of identically 
sized huts, and all the villagers mill around

doing fuck all but whine about tiny, pointless 
fetch quest items they want and won&#39;t even let

you wear their t-shirts. But much as Deus Ex 1&#39;s 
shooting, stealth, and RPGing mechanics were all

shitty in isolation, it was the intersection 
between them all where the magic happened.

And I was impressed by the way all Fantasy Life i: 
Everything But the Girl&#39;s gameplay loops fed into

each other like a bunch of snakes eating onion 
rings. You blacksmith better cooking equipment to

make better sandwiches so you can dungeon crawl to 
get more stuff to bring back to your village and

improve its rating so you can go safari in Breath 
of the Wild land for more villagers to form a

complete human pyramid to help you reach the shelf 
with the can opener so you can feed the cat that&#39;s

been sitting in front of the path to the rest of 
the story campaign for the last hour. A campaign

which culminates in the aforementioned craftathon, 
for which I had to scour Breath of the Wild land

for an alchemist, and as I was powerlevelling 
them in a high-level dungeon, I thought &quot;Boy,

this is hitting all the right receptors; I&#39;m 
glad it doesn&#39;t have too much evil grindathon

business that games use to trick you into getting 
obsessed.&quot; And then after the final boss and

credits roll, the game was like, &quot;Hey we unlocked 
a bunch of new objectives requiring a fuckload

of additional grinding; feel free to get obsessed 
with it.&quot; Er, you know what, I&#39;m good, game. This

isn&#39;t my Fantasy Life anymore. In my Fantasy Life, 
I leave the grinding to the girls with big bums.
